facts.fact: Kaspa’s technology is described as superior to Bitcoin’s, with a 6000x improvement over Satoshi’s protocol while preserving the same trust model.
facts.context: This highlights a significant technical advancement in protocol scalability and efficiency, positioning Kaspa as a competitive alternative to Bitcoin while adhering to a trustless, decentralized consensus.

source.title: In which we are all faceless until we have faces (Part I)*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: Kaspa’s architecture delegates network control to an anonymous set of miners, similar to Bitcoin’s model.
facts.context: Reinforces Kaspa's alignment with decentralized, permissionless security by relying on miners with competing, egoistic incentives.

source.title: In which we are all faceless until we have faces (Part I)*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: The “Crescendo” development team is credited with elite architecture and execution in advancing Kaspa’s protocol.
facts.context: Identifies the key developers behind major technical enhancements in the Kaspa protocol, relevant for assessing project progress and credibility.

source.title: In which we are all faceless until we have faces (Part I)*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: The existence of a centralized “official” social account for Kaspa was changed to “Kaspa (Unofficial)” by the author, Yonatan Sompolinsky, without prior consultation or a crisis management plan.
facts.context: Indicates an active move to decentralize or de-officialize project communication channels, reflecting a governance approach for Kaspa’s public identity.

source.title: In which we are all faceless until we have faces (Part I)*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: The future arrival of ASIC miners is expected for the Kaspa network; as of now, around 5.3% of Kaspa’s network hashrate is rentable on NiceHash.
facts.context: A shift to ASIC and CapEx-heavy mining reduces the feasibility of renting hashpower for attacks (such as via NiceHash), making 51% and similar attacks more difficult and increasing network security.

facts.fact: Kaspa’s consensus layer is optimized primarily for speed of confirmation, and secondarily for throughput capacity and decentralization.
facts.context: A fast confirmation layer is a critical technical feature for usability and security in blockchain networks.

facts.fact: CapEx-heavy (ASIC-dominated) mining is more energy efficient compared to OpEx-heavy (GPU-dominated) mining since a smaller fraction of the security budget is spent per block.
facts.context: Increased energy efficiency is significant for long-term sustainability, especially as Kaspa approaches its deflationary and no-new-minting phase.

facts.fact: Illiquidity in mining, fostered by ASIC/CapEx-heavy environments, supports fast confirmation times by preventing ephemeral, rented hashpower attacks.
facts.context: This design choice underpins Kaspa’s aim for “virtually instantaneous” confirmations without relying solely on number of confirmations or external finality gadgets.

facts.fact: Currently, approximately 5.3% of the Kaspa network’s hashrate is available for rental (e.g., via NiceHash).
facts.context: This metric is relevant to assessing the current risk profile for hashpower-rental based attacks as the network transitions toward ASIC mining.

facts.fact: DAGKNIGHT (DK) protocol was conceived by Yonatan Sompolinsky and Sutton and released to the public three years later, with detailed outstanding tasks documented in KIP #2.
facts.context: DK is an important consensus protocol being developed for Kaspa, and its outstanding tasks are formally tracked in a KIP.

facts.fact: The current grant proposal for continued DAGKNIGHT development requests 70 million KAS (70 MKAS), which constitutes approximately 0.5% of Kaspa's circulating supply.
facts.context: Funding magnitude and grant details show the scale of resources being allocated to protocol development.

facts.fact: A previous funded grant for Kaspa was for 100 million KAS (100 MKAS), which was about 1% of the then circulating supply.
facts.context: Indicates a precedent for significant community-funded development grants denominated in KAS.

facts.fact: The DAGKNIGHT protocol implementation on Kaspa will proceed regardless of grant outcome, but with uncertain timeline and priority if unfunded.
facts.context: Assurance that protocol advancement is intended, but underscores the role of funding in driving project timelines.

facts.fact: The preferred method for denominating deep-tech Kaspa development grants is in KAS tokens, not USD, to align with long-term incentives and community norms.
facts.context: Shows project approach towards grant structuring and developer incentives.

facts.fact: Ongoing and future work on DAGKNIGHT involves coordination between protocol researchers and developers, with technical milestones tracked in KIP #2.
facts.context: KIPs serve as the technical roadmap and accountability mechanism for protocol changes in Kaspa.

facts.fact: The DAGKNIGHT (DK) protocol, authored by Michal Sutton and Yonatan Sompolinsky, is claimed to be the first Proof-of-Work (POW) consensus protocol responsive to actual adversarial network latency and resilient to 49% byzantine attackers.
facts.context: This represents a significant advance in POW protocol design, improving network responsiveness and security against powerful adversaries.

facts.fact: The current DK protocol pseudocode is highly inefficient and needs further work to develop efficient algorithms for real-world implementation.
facts.context: Algorithmic efficiency is critical for practical deployment and adoption of the DK protocol in cryptocurrencies like Kaspa.

facts.fact: Before considering DK for Kaspa, the protocol needs: (i) proof section completion, (ii) paper preparation for peer-review, (iii) algorithmic efficiency improvements, and (iv) adaptation for minting regulation, difficulty control, and pruning.
facts.context: These steps are essential for transitioning DK from research to production-level use in Kaspa.

facts.fact: DK, like GHOSTDAG, enables high blocks-per-second (bps) rates with significantly faster confirmation times.
facts.context: Higher throughput and faster confirmations can improve user experience and scalability of the Kaspa blockchain.

facts.fact: Increasing blocks-per-second does not indefinitely reduce confirmation times, since higher bps increases relative latency and DAG width, and block headers become larger.
facts.context: This highlights practical scaling limits and the need for further research to determine optimal network parameters.

facts.fact: DK allows for potential features such as flexcaps—permitting miners to create blocks of different sizes and difficulties—which require consensus protocols like DK for high block rates.
facts.context: Flexcaps could enable higher peak throughput and better resource utilization during periods of high demand.

facts.fact: DK’s design does not require a fixed bound on DAG width, allowing it to cope with dynamically varying block rates and propagation delays.
facts.context: This increases network flexibility and resiliency especially under variable or peak network load conditions.

facts.fact: DK potentially enables stealth transactions, leveraging high bps asynchrony to protect users from MEV, and supports richer transaction fee mechanisms leveraging multiple parallel block creators.
facts.context: This improves privacy and can mitigate miner extractable value (MEV), which is critical as Kaspa moves towards supporting smart contracts.

facts.fact: The DK protocol operates in a partially synchronous mode and needs to be adapted to enforce responsive synchrony, especially for features like minting regulation, difficulty adjustment, and pruning.
facts.context: Responsiveness is vital for robust monetary policy and storage management on a live cryptocurrency.

facts.fact: Any upgrade to Kaspa’s consensus (specifically for adopting DK) will require a new grant request from the community, similar to the earlier Kaspa Rust code upgrade process.
facts.context: Community funding/approval is required for major technical upgrades, reflecting Kaspa’s decentralized development approach.

facts.fact: A proposal was made by Kaspa core developer Michael Sutton to refactor Kaspad, the Kaspa full-node software, by rewriting it in Rust.
facts.context: This aims to achieve an order-of-magnitude performance enhancement for Kaspad nodes and modernize the codebase.

facts.fact: The current Kaspad codebase is an adaptation of the Bitcoin client btcd, and it is written in Golang.
facts.context: This background explains the basis of the existing implementation and its inherited complexity.

facts.fact: The Kaspad codebase currently has significant technical debt and high code complexity, making contributions difficult for new developers.
facts.context: Refactoring and rewriting are expected to improve modularity and code legibility in addition to performance.

facts.fact: The Kaspa treasury is contribution-based and managed by a small number of volunteer original contributors.
facts.context: Limited resources restrict scalability and organizational initiatives for network adoption or development.

facts.fact: Demonstrating the original DAG (Directed Acyclic Graph) vision live via base layer node improvement is prioritized, with potential future consensus upgrades.
facts.context: The focus remains on evolving the DAG-based protocol in practical deployments, showing real-world readiness for consensus innovations.

facts.fact: The Kaspa network has changed its block reward mechanism from a random block reward averaging 500 Kaspa per block to a deterministic block reward of exactly 500 Kaspa per block.
facts.context: This change simplifies logic and debugging, ensures consistent mining rewards, and addresses unpredictability in mining income.

facts.fact: Average daily Kaspa emissions remain unchanged at 86,400 blocks x 500 Kaspa = 43,200,000 Kaspa per day, but are now deterministic.
facts.context: This confirms that the overall emission rate is stable; only the mechanism of reward calculation has changed.

facts.fact: An upcoming "rebase" is purely cosmetic, altering only the representation or nomenclature of supply amounts, not actual user balances or supply fractions.
facts.context: Users will retain the same share of total or circulating supply after the rebase, indicating no change to token economics or holdings.

facts.fact: The team intends to specify the deflationary monetary policy hard fork (HF) the week after network operations stabilize (after mining and syncing resume and developers are rested).
facts.context: A deflationary policy will directly affect long-term tokenomics; the timing indicates rollout after recent network recovery.

facts.fact: The Kaspa development team did not consider a rollback to an arbitrary earlier network state; instead, they sought the latest state with a "certainly-valid" UTXO commitment.
facts.context: This clarifies their approach to network recovery, maintaining consensus integrity by not discarding recent validated blocks and transactions unless necessary.

facts.fact: The team rebuilt the UTXO state using up-to-date and shared datadirs and verified it by computing the UTXO commitment hash, which resulted in 710f27df423e63aa6cdb72b89ea5a06cffa399d66f167704455b5af59def8e20.
facts.context: This process validated the correctness of the DAG UTXO algebra and confirmed that data was not lost or falsified, isolating the problem to a memory issue rather than an algebraic or consensus flaw.

facts.fact: The root cause of the network crash was a memory problem affecting the architecture of the module around the UTXO commitment and database interactions.
facts.context: Identifying this root cause helps direct future improvements to prevent similar failures, emphasizing the need for architectural enhancements.

facts.fact: Kaspa’s monetary policy will be deflationary, with a halving schedule that is more aggressive than Bitcoin’s.
facts.context: This affects supply, inflation, and long-term economics of the Kaspa cryptocurrency.

facts.fact: The initial block reward (currently averaging 500) and the activation time of the deflationary schedule are still to be determined and will be decided in the coming week.
facts.context: These parameters will define emission and ultimate coin cap.

facts.fact: Kaspa uses a proof-of-work called "k-heavy-hash," a Kaspa-specific variant of heavy-hash, designed to be CapEx-heavy.
facts.context: This choice impacts hardware requirements, energy efficiency, and resistance to mining centralization.

facts.fact: A hard fork is planned next week to fix a bug and decrease block header size.
facts.context: Hard forks can affect node and miner compatibility; reducing header size improves network efficiency.

facts.fact: A second hard fork is planned in the following weeks to embed the monetary policy.
facts.context: Embedding monetary policy at the protocol level is critical for coin emission and network predictability.

facts.fact: The roadmap is informal due to the community-driven, volunteer-based development structure.
facts.context: The absence of a formal roadmap means feature development and scheduling may be unpredictable.

facts.fact: Priority development goals are: fix bugs and issue updates, gradually scale up block rate to 10 blocks per second, and implement a consensus protocol upgrade pending ongoing research.
facts.context: Scaling block rate and consensus improvements directly affect throughput and reliability.

facts.fact: Future potential integration of privacy enhancements (e.g., bulletproofs) is identified as a desirable upgrade if contributors add it.
facts.context: Enhanced privacy features can improve security and user anonymity.

facts.fact: A block explorer deployment is planned for the following week.
facts.context: Block explorers aid transparency and user access to chain data.

facts.fact: The project’s core contributors are part-time and largely unfunded, with some DAGlabs support, but there is no central company or entity responsible for network operation or user funds.
facts.context: Decentralized development minimizes single points of failure but may slow progress.

facts.fact: Users are free to stress test UTXO throughput, but bug fixes may be delayed due to limited developer availability.
facts.context: Testing throughput can reveal scalability limits, but slow response to bugs could impact network reliability.

facts.fact: Kaspa is proposed to launch initially in "gamenet" mode, an experimental research-oriented network.
facts.context: This unorthodox launch mode is designed to facilitate experimentation with cryptoeconomic attacks and novel consensus behavior rather than immediate production use.

facts.fact: The initial Kaspa launch will deliberately include a semi-scarce, randomly-parameterized monetary policy, resulting in uncertain token scarcity.
facts.context: Intentionally ambiguous scarcity discourages commercialization and exchange listing, focusing instead on research and testing.

facts.fact: Kaspa's early gamenet phase is intended to be CPU/GPU-mineable, with Ethash identified as a suitable mining algorithm candidate.
facts.context: This choice promotes accessibility for a broad audience and testing by communities not committed to ASICs or established chains.

facts.fact: Kaspa will initially lack EVM support.
facts.context: This limits compatibility with existing Ethereum smart contracts and tooling in the early phases.

facts.fact: The gamenet reward structure will deliberately incentivize attack simulations such as reorgs and selfish-mining, mirroring real-world block reordering and MEV scenarios.
facts.context: The approach is meant to stress-test the consensus mechanism and study attack/defense dynamics under adversarial network conditions.

facts.fact: Plans are laid for developing an Ethereum bridge for Kaspa gamenet 2.0, enabling practical MEV-reorg testing and simulation.
facts.context: This would allow cross-chain experimentation with MEV scenarios and interoperation with DeFi incentives.

facts.fact: The transition from gamenet to mainnet will involve a shift to a solidified, scarcity-based monetary policy, retroactively compensating early miners for their experimental participation.
facts.context: This incentivizes participation during the experimental phase while providing a clear pathway to a standard, exchange-compatible mainnet.

facts.fact: Kaspa is designed to act as a testbed for R&D groups, enabling them to test proposals and cryptoeconomic defenses (e.g., MEV strategies, cryptographic primitives).
facts.context: The system targets researchers, attracting novel development and insight into the effectiveness of various blockchain defense mechanisms.

facts.fact: The article discusses an SPV (Simplified Payment Verification) sync mode based on multiplicative-hash UTXO-commitments.
facts.context: This describes a specific approach to light client synchronization in Kaspa using multiplicative-hash commitments to the UTXO set, which has implications for how efficiently and securely new nodes can join and verify the state of the network without downloading the entire transaction history.

source.title: In which mayday mayday we are syncing about*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: The author argues that checking a cryptocurrency's predictable issuance and decentralization is more important for users than verifying the historical validity of every transaction.
facts.context: This perspective affects node software design and user priorities, suggesting that consensus on the current state and the network’s economic majority is more critical than absolute historical consistency.

source.title: In which mayday mayday we are syncing about*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: The consensus goal for cryptocurrency systems, as presented, is facilitating agreement (social consensus) rather than strictly enforcing historical transaction consistency.
facts.context: This view impacts how consensus mechanisms may be designed or justified, focusing on practical agreement among users rather than absolute code-based historical validity.

source.title: In which mayday mayday we are syncing about*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: Fast block times (block liveness) can directly reduce cryptocurrency confirmation times in paradigms where merchants wait for a specific number of blocks before considering a transaction irreversible.
facts.context: This suggests that faster block production can improve user experience by reducing the time merchants and users need to wait for transaction finality in certain threat models.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: There are two paradigms for confirmation waiting in crypto payments: one based on a sufficient number of confirmed blocks, and another based on an absolute amount of time passing.
facts.context: Understanding these paradigms is important for protocol and user-interface design, as improvements in block production affect only the first (block-count) paradigm.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: Miners protect the network by spending resources (electricity, hardware) to mine blocks, with the system’s security budget corresponding to mining revenue per hour.
facts.context: Highlights the economic dynamics of blockchain security, since the actual value spent on mining at any given time is a critical factor in deterring attacks.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: The article references the Kaspa project (github.com/kaspanet) as an example of an initiative focused on tackling issues of fast block rates.
facts.context: Kaspa explores technological improvements that seek to enable fast block times without sacrificing decentralization or security.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: Accelerating block times does not reduce confirmation waiting for users or merchants who base their confirmation risk tolerance on an absolute time parameter, as opposed to a number-of-blocks parameter.
facts.context: This distinction is technically significant, as optimizations for faster blocks may have limited user-facing benefit depending on economic or adversarial risk consideration models.

source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

technical.fact: Kaspa’s technology is described as superior to Bitcoin’s, with a 6000x improvement over Satoshi’s protocol while preserving the same trust model.
technical.context: This highlights a significant technical advancement in protocol scalability and efficiency, positioning Kaspa as a competitive alternative to Bitcoin while adhering to a trustless, decentralized consensus.

source.title: In which mayday mayday we are syncing about*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

mining.fact: The future arrival of ASIC miners is expected for the Kaspa network; as of now, around 5.3% of Kaspa’s network hashrate is rentable on NiceHash.
mining.context: A shift to ASIC and CapEx-heavy mining reduces the feasibility of renting hashpower for attacks (such as via NiceHash), making 51% and similar attacks more difficult and increasing network security.

mining.fact: CapEx-heavy (ASIC-dominated) mining is more energy efficient compared to OpEx-heavy (GPU-dominated) mining since a smaller fraction of the security budget is spent per block.
mining.context: Increased energy efficiency is significant for long-term sustainability, especially as Kaspa approaches its deflationary and no-new-minting phase.

mining.fact: Currently, approximately 5.3% of the Kaspa network’s hashrate is available for rental (e.g., via NiceHash).
mining.context: This metric is relevant to assessing the current risk profile for hashpower-rental based attacks as the network transitions toward ASIC mining.

mining.fact: The Kaspa network has changed its block reward mechanism from a random block reward averaging 500 Kaspa per block to a deterministic block reward of exactly 500 Kaspa per block.
mining.context: This change simplifies logic and debugging, ensures consistent mining rewards, and addresses unpredictability in mining income.

mining.fact: Average daily Kaspa emissions remain unchanged at 86,400 blocks x 500 Kaspa = 43,200,000 Kaspa per day, but are now deterministic.
mining.context: This confirms that the overall emission rate is stable; only the mechanism of reward calculation has changed.

mining.fact: Kaspa uses a proof-of-work called "k-heavy-hash," a Kaspa-specific variant of heavy-hash, designed to be CapEx-heavy.
mining.context: This choice impacts hardware requirements, energy efficiency, and resistance to mining centralization.

mining.fact: Kaspa's early gamenet phase is intended to be CPU/GPU-mineable, with Ethash identified as a suitable mining algorithm candidate.
mining.context: This choice promotes accessibility for a broad audience and testing by communities not committed to ASICs or established chains.

security.fact: Illiquidity in mining, fostered by ASIC/CapEx-heavy environments, supports fast confirmation times by preventing ephemeral, rented hashpower attacks.
security.context: This design choice underpins Kaspa’s aim for “virtually instantaneous” confirmations without relying solely on number of confirmations or external finality gadgets.

security.fact: DK potentially enables stealth transactions, leveraging high bps asynchrony to protect users from MEV, and supports richer transaction fee mechanisms leveraging multiple parallel block creators.
security.context: This improves privacy and can mitigate miner extractable value (MEV), which is critical as Kaspa moves towards supporting smart contracts.

security.fact: The team rebuilt the UTXO state using up-to-date and shared datadirs and verified it by computing the UTXO commitment hash, which resulted in 710f27df423e63aa6cdb72b89ea5a06cffa399d66f167704455b5af59def8e20.
security.context: This process validated the correctness of the DAG UTXO algebra and confirmed that data was not lost or falsified, isolating the problem to a memory issue rather than an algebraic or consensus flaw.

security.fact: The root cause of the network crash was a memory problem affecting the architecture of the module around the UTXO commitment and database interactions.
security.context: Identifying this root cause helps direct future improvements to prevent similar failures, emphasizing the need for architectural enhancements.

security.fact: The gamenet reward structure will deliberately incentivize attack simulations such as reorgs and selfish-mining, mirroring real-world block reordering and MEV scenarios.
security.context: The approach is meant to stress-test the consensus mechanism and study attack/defense dynamics under adversarial network conditions.

mining / security.fact: Miners protect the network by spending resources (electricity, hardware) to mine blocks, with the system’s security budget corresponding to mining revenue per hour.
mining / security.context: Highlights the economic dynamics of blockchain security, since the actual value spent on mining at any given time is a critical factor in deterring attacks.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky
